prompt: Write a poem about underpass echo in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Echoing Arch

'Twas brilling in the underpass,
The echoes mimsy and mazy,
All flimsy were the sound waves cast,
Reverberating crazy.

"Beware the Echo-Arch, my son!
The walls that bounce, the noises scatter!
Beware the Jabber-talk, and shun
The babbling Chatter-matter!"

He took his verbal sword in hand;
Long time the sound-foe sought he—
Then rested he by the tunnel tree
And stood awhile in thought-ee.

And, as in musing mood he stood, 
The Echo-Arch, with tones of flame,
Came whiffling through the stony wood,
And babbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The verbal blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Echo-Arch?
Come to my arms, my noisy boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brilling in the underpass,
The echoes mimsy and mazy,
All flimsy were the sound waves cast,
Reverberating crazy.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
"The Misting Morn"

'Twas brilling in the misty morn,
The foggy tendrils did entwine,
All mimsy were the trees forlorn,
And the dew drops bedecked the vine.

Beware the Foggy Morn, my friend!
The haze that blurs, the chill that bites!
Beware the Mist-Wraith and attend
The Vapor-Sprite with glowing lights!

It lingered in the murky air,
So long it tarried, oh so cold,
The damp and drear were everywhere,
Till sun did breach its clammy hold.

And as the warming rays did shine,
The Foggy Morn, its time did bide.
It burbled as it did decline,
And murmured as it slipped aside.

'Twas brilling all that misty morn,
The sun had conquered, warmth did reign.
The air was clear, the chill was shorn,
And morning fog had gone again.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about desire path in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Desirous Tread

'Twas brilling, and the slithy toves
Did gyre and gimble 'cross the green;
All mimsy were the borogoves,
And the desire path was seen.

"Beware the beaten track, my son!
The ruts that bite, the mud that catches!
Beware the shortcut's lure, and shun
The frumious path that matches!"

He took his vorpal boots in hand;
Long time the tempting way he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in plodding thought he stood,
The desire path, with easeful lure,
Came winding through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it wore!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The grassy sward his soles did smash!
He left the proper trail askew,
And with his feet went thrash!

"And hast thou forged the path untried?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brilling, and the slithy toves
Did gyre and gimble 'cross the green;
All mimsy were the borogoves,
And the desire path was seen.
label: medium

All mimsy were the PowerPoints,

He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Map-a-wock?

O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

All mimsy were the contour lines,

poem:
The Pixels' Plight

'Twas brillig, and the slithy toves
Did gyre and gimble on the screen;
All mimsy were the images,
And the pixels worn and lean.

"Beware the screen burn-in, my son!
The ghosts that haunt, the lines that stay!
Beware the static image's fun,
And shun prolonged display!"

He took his vorpal remote in hand;
Long time the power button sought—
So rested he by the TV tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The screen burn-in, with lines of flame,
Came whiffling through the digital wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal remote went snicker-snack!
He turned it off, and with a scoff
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the screen burn-in?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, and the slithy toves
Did gyre and gimble on the screen;
All clear were the images,
And the pixels fresh and keen.

prompt: Compose a poem on stage wings in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Fluttering Folds

'Twas brillig, and the stage wings wide
Did flap and flutter, side to side,
All mimsy were the actor-folk,
And the curtains outgrabe.

"Beware the Wing-flap, my dear boy!
The folds that snag, the ropes that cloy!
Beware the Prop-crash and eschew
The frumious Set-destroy!"

He took his scripted lines in hand;
Long time the opening cue he planned—
So rested he by the Stage-wing tree
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in nervous thought he stood,
The Wing-flap, with folds of velvet-wood,
Came whiffling through the backstage-ish,
And burbled as it swished!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The actor's focus went snicker-snack!
He nailed his lines, the curtains fell,
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the dread Wing-flap?
Come to my arms, my thespian chap!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, and the stage wings wide
Did flap and flutter, side to side,
All mimsy were the actor-folk,
And the curtains outgrabe.

prompt: Create a poem about brown butter in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Ballad of the Beurre Marron

'Twas brillig in the kitchen bright,
The chef, with whisk in hand,
Began to cook with great delight,
A treat from dairy land.

He took the butter, golden hue,
And placed it in a pan,
The heat beneath, the bubbles grew,
The transformation ran.

The butter danced and swirled about,
Its scent filled all the air,
The chef, he stirred and watched throughout,
With diligence and care.

The hue turned amber, then marron,
The milk solids did brown,
A nutty aroma, like a song,
Enchanting all around.

Behold! The brown butter, a sight,
A flavor rich and bold,
In sauces, bakes, or simple bites,
A treasure to behold.

So if you seek a flavor grand,
A twist on butter's tale,
The brown butter, a culinary wand,
Will make your dishes hale!
label: very_low

prompt: Write a poem about creep in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Creeping Crud

'Twas creepy, and the slithy grime
Did seep and slither 'cross the floor.
All queasy were the victim's chimes,
And the foul stench did soar.

Beware the Creeping Crud, my friend!
The ooze that spreads, the slime that clings!
Beware the Fungus Fiend, and tend
To cleanse these wretched things!

He scrubbed and scoured with all his might,
With brush and brew he fought the crud.
Then rested he by bleach-light,
And stood awhile in suds.

And as in fresher thought he stood,
The Creeping Crud, with goop anew,
Came squelching through the neighborhood,
And oozed the alley through!

Mop-mop! Sponge-sponge! And through and through
The bleach went splashing thick and far!
He left it clean, and with relief
He went galumphing bar.

'Twas hygienic, and the shiny tile
Now gleamed and glistened crud all clear.
No grime was seen, not for a while,
And all did brightly cheer!
label: medium

poem:
The Piercing Prowler

'Twas brillig, and the slithy awl
Did jab and puncture in the night:
All flimsy were the leather sprawl,
And the hide ripped out of sight.

"Beware the Piercing Prowler, son!
The point that pokes, the shaft that drives!
Beware the Jabber-Awl, and shun
The furious Gimlet-Knives!"

He took his vorpal blade in hand;
Long time the holey foe he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Piercing Prowler, eyes of flame,
Came stitching through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Piercing Prowler?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, and the slithy awl
Did jab and puncture in the night:
All flimsy were the leather sprawl,
And the hide ripped out of sight.

prompt: Create a poem about third rail hum in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Buzzing Bard

'Twas brilling, and the slithy toves
Did gyre and gimble 'neath the ground;
All mimsy were the rail-lit groves,
And the wire's hum a constant sound.

"Beware the third rail's buzz, my son!
The amps that bite, the volts that catch!
Beware the spark-bird's flashing fun,
And shun the frumious power-snatch!"

He took his insul-gloves in hand;
Long time the humming foe he sought—
So rested he by the tunnel-tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in wary thought he stood,
The third rail, with its eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the shielded wood,
And buzzed as if to stake its claim!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The rubber soles went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, with wires of red,
And went galumphing back.

"And hast thou tamed the third rail's hum?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brilling, and the slithy toves
Did gyre and gimble 'neath the ground;
The rail's strange song no longer rose,
Its humming now forever drowned.

prompt: Create a poem about science fair in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Fabulous Fair of Science

'Twas brillig, and the science fair
  Did lure and beckon, far and near,
All mimsy were the students there,
  With projects bold, and ideas clear.

"Beware the pseudo-sci, my boy!
  The claims that lie, the facts that twist!
Beware the hype-bird, and avoid
  The frumious journalist!"

He took his vorpal mind in hand;
  Long time the peerless prize he sought—
So rested he by the poster-tree,
  And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in curious thought he stood,
  The pseudo-sci, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the science-wood,
  And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
  The vorpal mind went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
  He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the pseudo-sci?
  Come to my arms, my brilliant boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
  He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, and the science fair
  Did lure and beckon, far and near,
All mimsy were the students there,
  With projects bold, and ideas clear.

prompt: Write a poem about film camera in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Snapshotte

'Twas brillig, and the aperture 
Did focus and expose the light;
All filmy were the canisters,
And the shutters clicked just right.

"Beware the Snapshotte, my friend! 
The lens that zooms, the flash that blinds!
Beware the Qwikprintz, and shun
The Polaroidish kinds!"

He took his loaded film in hand;
Long time the perfect shot he sought—
So rested he near the Tri-pode tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in pensive thought he stood,
The Snapshotte, with lens of glass,
Came whirring through the peopled wood,
And shuttered as it pass'd!

Snap! Snap! And snap again!
The shutter went with every take;
He shot the film, and with a grin,
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou snapped the Snapshotte?
Come to my arms, my shutterous boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, and the aperture
Did focus and expose the light;
All filmy were the canisters,
And the shutters clicked just right.
label: high

So rested he by the IT stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Printerjam?
Come to my arms, my office boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, and the office crew

All shiny were the printed pages,

All mimsy were the roulette spins,

poem:
The Minstrel's Melodious Menagerie

'Twas rhythm, and the tuneful tones
Did harmonize and chord in time:
All major were the melliflues,
And the pitch sublime.

The notes that trill, the keys that catch!
Beware the Trumpet's call, and shun
The frumious Snare-Dispatch!"

So rested he by the Timbre tree
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in meter thought he stood,
The Minstrel, with his song-filled eyes,
Came piping through the scale-wood,
Composing symphonies!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The fork-ed prongs went pitch-and-catch!
He left it dead, its beats unread,
And went galumphing back.

"And hast thou tuned the Minstrel's voice?
Come to my staff, my tuneful boy!
O frabjous day! Staccato! Sway!"
He chorused in his joy.

'Twas rhythm, and the tuneful tones
Did harmonize and chord in time:
All major were the melliflues,
And the pitch sublime.

poem:
The Sizzling Saucepan

'Twas brillig, and the nutty scent
Did waft and tantalize the nose;
All creamy were the butter bent,
And the stove-top glows.

"Beware the browned butter, my son!
The pans that sear, the foam that fades!
Beware the milk solids that shun,
The golden hue pervades!"

He took his wooden spoon in hand;
Long time the sputt'ring foe he sought—
So rested he by the stove-top tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in pensive thought he stood,
The browned butter, with taste so grand,
Came swirling through the saucepan 'hood,
Enticing, rich and tanned!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The wooden spoon went stir-stir-stir!
He left it done, and with spoon won,
He went galumphing sure.

"And hast thou stirred the browned butter?
Come to my arms, my nutty boy!
O splendid day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, and the nutty scent
Did waft and tantalize the nose;
All creamy were the butter bent,
And the stove-top glows.

  The creep crept back.

"And hast thou slain the Creepster?

O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
  He chortled in his joy.

And the gate signs outgrabe.

"Beware the Layover, my son!
The waits that bite, the lines that catch!
Beware the Luggage beast, and shun
The frumious Lost-and-Snatch!"

He took his boarding pass in hand;
Long time the gate sign he sought—
So rested he by the Check-In tree
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Layover, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
His rolling case went clicker-clack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Layover?
Come to my arms, my gleamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas transit, and the weary troves
Did gyre and gimble in the bay:
All flimsy were the travel robes,
And the gate signs outgrabe.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on conference room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
"The Conferwocky"

'Twas brillig, and the conference room
  Did gyre and gimble with projectors bright:
All mimsy were the PowerPoints,
  And the whiteboards outgrabe.

"Beware the Conferwock, my son!
  The jaws that bite, the claws that catch!
Beware the Jargon-bird, and shun
  The frumious Bandersnatch!"

He took his vorpal pen in hand;
  Long time the lexicon foe he sought—
So rested he by the Breakroom tree
  And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
  The Conferwock, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
  And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
  The vorpal pen went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
  He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Conferwock?
  Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
  He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, and the conference room
  Did gyre and gimble with projectors bright:
All mimsy were the PowerPoints,
  And the whiteboards outgrabe.

prompt: Create a poem about awl in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Awl's Brawl

'Twas brillig, and the slithy awl
Did gyre and gimble in the wabe:
All mimsy were the borogoves,
And the mome raths outgrabe.

"Beware the Awl, my son!
The point that pierces, the edge that cuts!
Beware the Jabber-hole, and shun
The frumious Bandersnatch!"

He took his vorpal tool in hand;
Long time the holey foe he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Awl, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Awly beast?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, and the slithy awl
Did gyre and gimble in the wabe:
All mimsy were the borogoves,
And the mome raths outgrabe.

prompt: Write a poem about creep in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Creeping Creep

'Twas eerie, in the darkened room,
The creep did lurk and loom.
All sly and sneaky were his steps,
Beneath the midnight moon.

Beware the creeping creep, my friend!
His leering eyes aglow,
His slinky slink and slippery slide,
That fill the night with woe.

He creeps and crawls through shadow's veil,
With malice in his heart.
A spine-chilling, skin-crawling, hair-raising
Fiend from night's dark art.

So watch your step and guard your soul,
When darkness falls anew.
For in the gloom, the creeping creep
May come a-creeping for you!
label: low

prompt: Compose a poem on desire path in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Trailblazer's Tread

'Twas brillig, and the slithy toves
Did gyre and gimble 'cross the green;
All mimsy were the borogoves,
And the desire path sheen.

"Beware the beaten track, my son!
The ruts that bite, the mud that catches!
Beware the shortcut's lure, and shun
The frumious path that matches!"

He took his vorpal boots in hand;
Long time the poundment foe he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The desire path, with sods of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The muddy boots went clitter-clack!
He left it dead, the path of dread,
And with its paving hied him back.

"And hast thou slain the desire path?
Come to my arms, my trailsome boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brillig, and the slithy toves
Did gyre and gimble 'cross the green;
All mimsy were the borogoves,
And the desire path sheen.
label: medium

prompt: Create a poem about morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
"The Mist of Morn"

'Twas brilling in the misty morn,
The foggy fields did sway and swirl,
All mimsy were the trees forlorn,
And the dew drops did unfurl.

Beware the Morning Fog, my friend!
The haze that hides, the sight it blends!
Beware the Murky-Mist, and shun
The frumious Vapor-Sun!

He took his vorpal blade in hand:
Long time the hazy foe he sought—
So rested he by the Tumtum tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in uffish thought he stood,
The Morning Fog, with eyes of flame,
Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,
And burbled as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vorpal blade went snicker-snack!
He left it dead, and with its head
He went galumphing back.

"And hast thou slain the Morning Fog?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brilling in the misty morn,
The foggy fields did sway and swirl,
All mimsy were the trees forlorn,
And the dew drops did unfurl.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about third rail hum in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Thrumming of the Third Rail 

'Twas brilling on the subway track,
The trains did gyre and gimble back.
All mimsy were the turnstiles old,
And the token takers, they cajoled.  

Beware the Third Rail hum, my son!
The volts that bite, the amps that catch!
Beware the live wire's sparking ton,
And shun the frumious power latch!

He took his pliers and meter lead 
And sought the buzzing rail with dread.
Then rested he by the pillar lum,
And stood awhile in thought (ho hum).

And as in pensive mood he stood,
The Third Rail thrummed, with current good,
Came whiffling through the tunnels dim,
And burbled as it hummed to him!

Ohm-ward! Ohm-ward! with resistance fought! 
His clamp-on meter went snicker-snack!
He checked the volts and, circuit fraught, 
He went galumphing safely back.

"And hast thou probed the Third Rail hum?
Come to my arms, my meter-boy!
Oh faraday! Coulomb! Watt ho!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas brilling on the subway track,
The trains did gyre and gimble back.  
All mimsy were the turnstiles old,
Power flowing, as the current rolled!
label: medium

prompt: Compose a poem on film camera in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Snaptured Smile

'Twas brillig, and the shutterbug
  Did snap and shutter in the light:
All flimsy were the film canug,
  And the lens outgrabe.

"Beware the Snaptured Smile, my son!
  The apertures that blink, the flash that catches!
Beware the Daguerre bird, and shun
  The frumious Polargraph!"

He took his tripod stand in hand;
  Long time the view finder he sought—
So rested he by the Kodak tree
  And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in silver thought he stood,
  The Snaptured Smile, with eyes of flame,
Came whirring through the celluloide wood,
  And burbled as it came!

Snap! Snap! And snap again!
  The tripod stand went snicker-snack!
He captured it, with great élan,
  And went galumphing back.

"And hast thou shot the Snaptured Smile?
  Come to my arms, my shutterboysh lad!
O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
  He chortled, undismayed.

'Twas brillig, and the shutterbug
  Did snap and shutter in the light:
All flimsy were the film canug,
  And the lens outgrabe.
label: high
